byline.contributor: Alison Smale reported from Berlin, and James Kanter from Brussels. Ceylan Yeginsu contributed reporting from Istanbul.
byline.original: By ALISON SMALE and JAMES KANTER

abstract: Increasingly authoritarian actions of Turkish Pres Recep Tayyip Erdogan, including his ouster of Prime Min Ahmet Davutoglu, have caused European leaders to doubt migrant deal struck with Turkey and their reliance on nation to deal with tide of refugees.

headline.print_headline: Tensions Threaten E.U. Deal With Turkey
headline.main: President Erdogan’s Authoritarian Tilt Threatens Visa Deal With Europe

keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
keywords.name: subject

snippet: Responding to calls for Turkey to bring its security laws into line with European Union norms, the Turkish president said his country “will not change its antiterror law for the sake of a visa deal.”
lead_paragraph: Responding to calls for Turkey to bring its security laws into line with European Union norms, the Turkish president said his country “will not change its antiterror law for the sake of a visa deal.”
